title: 111_hr3684
content: The Act is titled the "American Small Business Innovation Act" and includes a table of contents outlining the New Markets Venture Capital Program. The "American Small Business Innovation Act" includes the New Markets Venture Capital Program, which aims to expand investment opportunities for small manufacturers in low-income areas. It also establishes the Angel Investment Program to support startup companies. SEC. 101. EXPANSION OF NEW MARKETS VENTURE CAPITAL PROGRAM. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration shall evaluate the success of the program and submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 102. IMPROVED NATIONWIDE DISTRIBUTION. SEC. 102. IMPROVED NATIONWIDE DISTRIBUTION. The Administrator will approve at least one company from each geographic region of the Small Business Administration for increased investment in small manufacturers. SEC. 103. INCREASED INVESTMENT IN SMALL MANUFACTURERS. Amends the Small Business Investment Act to require conditionally approved companies focused on small manufacturers to raise $3,000,000 of private capital from eligible investors. SEC. 104. UPDATING DEFINITION OF LOW-INCOME GEOGRAPHIC AREA. SEC. 104 updates the definition of a low-income geographic area in the Small Business Investment Act by aligning it with the definition of a low-income community in the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 105 requires a study on the availability of equity capital in low-income urban and rural areas, to be conducted by the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. A report with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of completing the study. Operational Assistance Grants to Conditionally Approved Companies: Section 358(a) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include grants for conditionally approved companies. Companies must repay the grant if they do not enter into a participation agreement for final approval. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include grants for conditionally approved companies. If a company receives a grant and final approval, the grant amount will be deducted from the total operational assistance grant. The maximum grant amount a company can receive is $50,000. Time for final approval is limited to 2 years. Operational assistance definition is expanded. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include assistance for implementing energy efficiency and sustainable practices to reduce environmental impact and costs while improving employee health. SEC. 107. The Small Business Administration will create standard documents for the New Markets Venture Capital program application to reduce costs for companies. SEC. 108. Matching requirement eliminated from the Small Business Investment Act. SEC. 109. Operational assistance grants will have a simplified formula. SEC. 109. The formula for operational assistance grants under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is simplified to be the lesser of 10 percent of resources raised by the company or $1,000,000. SEC. 110. Authorization of appropriations is extended to fiscal years 2010 through 2012. TITLE II--ANGEL INVESTMENT PROGRAM establishes an Angel Investment Program. Title III of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to establish an Angel Investment Program under PART D. This includes the creation of an Office of Angel Investment. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to establish the Office of Angel Investment within the Small Business Administration. The Director of Angel Investment will support angel investment opportunities for small businesses and administer various programs under sections 399C, 399D, and 399E. The term 'angel group' refers to a group of 10 or more accredited investors actively involved in evaluating and making investments in local or regional small businesses. An 'angel investor' is an individual who provides capital to small business concerns and meets the criteria of an accredited investor. The terms 'small business concern owned and controlled by veterans', 'small business concern owned and controlled by women', and 'socially and economically disadvantaged small business concern' are defined under specific sections of the Small Business Act. "SEC. 399C. ANGEL INVESTMENT PROGRAM." The Angel Investment Program, established by the Director of Angel Investment, provides financing to approved angel groups for venture capital investment in small business concerns. To be eligible, angel groups must have experience investing in local businesses, established protocols, a code of ethics, and submit an application to the Director. The funds received must be used according to the program guidelines. The Angel Investment Program provides financing to angel groups for investments in small businesses that meet specific criteria, including being less than 5 years old, having fewer than 75 employees, and having a majority of employees in the United States. Each angel group can receive up to $2,000,000 in financing, and the geographic area for investments is determined by the Director. The Director determines the geographic area for small businesses to receive financing from angel groups. Priority is given to veteran, women-owned, and socially disadvantaged small businesses. Financing is distributed nationwide and angel groups must match the funding received. The angel group receiving financing must invest an equal or greater amount from a non-government source. Repayment is required for profitable investments, and an Angel Investment Fund is established in the Treasury. The Angel Investment Fund established in the Treasury will receive deposits collected under subsection (i) for financing purposes without fiscal year limitations. Authorization of appropriations includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. The Federal Angel Network, established under SEC. 399D, will receive deposits for financing purposes without fiscal year limitations. Authorization of appropriations includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. The Director of Angel Investment will establish the Federal Angel Network, a searchable database to help small businesses find angel investors. It will include a list of angel groups and investors, their investment types, and other relevant resources. The Director will collect and regularly update the information in the network. The Director will ensure regular updates to the Federal Angel Network. Angel investors can request exclusion from the network. The network will be available on the Administration's website for download and use. $1,000,000 is authorized for this section. "Grant program for development of angel groups authorized with $1,000,000 funding." The Director of Angel Investment will establish a grant program for eligible entities to develop new or existing angel groups and promote awareness about angel investing. Eligible entities include government entities, nonprofits, Small Business Development Centers, and women's business centers. Grants will require a matching contribution from the recipient. The grant program established by the Director of Angel Investment requires eligible entities to provide a matching contribution of 50 percent of the grant amount. To apply for the grant, entities must submit a proposal and any additional information requested by the Director. A report evaluating the grant's use and success of the angel group must be submitted within 3 years. $1,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012.
